item.title: Festive 500
item.description: 2020 has been something of a challenge in so many ways. There’s been just enough time for a final personal test.

item.title: Taxing Affairs
item.description: Amazon and Jeff Bezos are currently drawing ire over the amount of tax they pay and the wealth they have amassed respectively.

item.title: Make It So
item.description: I’m a big fan of automating repetitive work with a Makefile, especially when multiple steps or dependency chains are involved.

item.title: Asking Too Much
item.description: One of the key tenets of information and computer security is the Princicple of Least Privilege; an appliction should only request – and be granted – the minimum permissions required for the role it is trying to fulfil.

item.title: Maintenance
item.description: The software project lifecycle doesn’t usually end with delivery. If it’s not looked after properly, a project can often still cause you pain way beyond this stage.

item.title: Recorded History
item.description: I was first introduced to version control systems twenty years ago, first with CVS and then SVN. These days, like most others, I’m using Git. Over the years, various models and strategies have emerged for VCS best practice.

item.title: Missing August
item.description: In ordinary times, Edinburgh usually welcomes the world to the International Festival this month. This year was clearly always going to be different.

item.title: Working From Home isn't Working for Me
item.description: From skimming LinkedIn posts over the past few months, it’s been obvious that plenty of people are loving working from home. I am, however, not one of them.

item.title: The Herring Road
item.description: I got myself out of the city yesterday evening for a solo adventure, exploring part of a historical route across the Lammermuir Hills.

item.title: A Right Set Up
item.description: There’s a popular IT anology of treating servers as cattle rather than pets. Logically, does it then follow that my laptop is a cow?

item.title: Out With the Old
item.description: They say that you should never reinvent the wheel. But what if you could make the wheels better?

item.title: Confessions of a Bashist
item.description: I prefer some things to be done a certain way but my reasons are seldom irrational – usually there’s at least some logic involved somewhere.

item.title: Shellology
item.description: As a follow up to my previous Unix archaeology, I traced the evolution of shell development across the decades.

item.title: My Descent into Shell
item.description: For my first lightning talk, I dived into the history of Unix to find the starting point from which modern shells emerged.

item.title: Struck by Lightning
item.description: Researching and presenting to my colleagues – or learning new things from them – is proving to be a great distraction.

item.title: Documentation
item.description: It is a fact that individual contributors to a codebase will come and go. Establishing good documentation practices is essential to enable an effective organisational memory.

item.title: Super Styling
item.description: I’m gradually getting to grips with Hugo, learning about how the build process, shortcodes and templates all work.

item.title: Home Economics
item.description: Long winters growing up in the Pennines seems to have set me in good stead for the current situation and empty shelves in the shops.

item.title: You Can't Always Get What You Want
item.description: I had some pretty specific requirements regarding a theme for my blog but I couldn’t find anything that ticked all my boxes.

item.title: Starting Afresh
item.description: I’ve resurrected my blog, having said goodbye to WordPress, and embraced a static generation approach with Hugo.
